prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Yujin Mikotoba
Description: A medical school professor at the Imperial Yumei University. He's an authority in forensic medicine, and Miss Susato's father.
Character 4
Name: Seishiro Jigoku
Description: The Minister of Foreign Affairs and a judge of the Supreme Court of Judicature in Japan. He's the man who acquitted me when I was once accused of murder.
Character 5
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 8
Name: Evie Vigil
Description: A client who has engaged the services of Mr Sholmes. She has asked the great detective to help track down her missing husband.
Character 9
Name: Daley Vigil
Description: A man who's disappeared without a word to his family. He was the former chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Character 10
Name: Barry Caidin
Description: The governor of Barclay Prison. It seems he was good friends with Professor Mikotoba during the Japanese man's time in Britain as a visiting student.
Character 11
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: A murdered Scotland Yard inspector. He was stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 12
Name: Kazuma Asogi
Description: My best friend, who I had believed to be dead. He lost his memory somehow, but has now materialised as a prosecutor in the British courts.
Character 13
Name: Gossip
Description: A pedlar plying his trade on Fresno Street. He seems to make his money selling interesting items of news to passers-by.
Character 14
Name: Venus
Description: A pedlar plying her trade on Fresno Street. She seems to make her money selling meagre little fireworks to children.
Character 15
Name: Sandwich
Description: A mysterious 'signpost' who can be found on Fresno street. He looks familiar somehow...
Character 16
Name: Fabien de Rousseau
Description: The fraudster behind the Red-Headed League swindle, who was caught by Mr Sholmes. He derives from the French aristocracy, it seems.
Character 17
Name: Peppino de Rossi
Description: A lackey of de Rousseau and conspirator in the Red-Headed League swindle. The third son of a great Italian landowner.
Character 18
Name: Maria Gorey
Description: The daughter of Dr Sithe who's also a coroner like her mother. She carries out all the autopsy work on corpses.

Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1

Evidence 2
Name: Photograph of Mr Vigil
Description: A photographic print received from Mrs Vigil in order to aid with locating her missing husband. He appears to have no particularly distinctive facial features.
Evidence 3

Evidence 4
Name: Dismissal Notice
Description: The harsh reprimand incurred by Mr Vigil ten years ago that resulted in him losing his job as chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Evidence 5
Name: Red Hairpiece
Description: A flame-red wig found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Presumably it belonged to Inspector Gregson...
Evidence 6
Name: Candelabrum
Description: A candelabrum from the wall of the room on Fresno Street where the inspector was found dead. The top of one of the candles appears to have been blown off.
Evidence 7
Name: Revolver
Description: The murder weapon that was found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Probably best to avoid handling it.
Evidence 8
Name: Policeman Figurine
Description: A small and rather endearing model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. A model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Giving it a twist causes a key-like shaft to pop out from the base.
Evidence 9
Name: Framed Photograph
Description: A photographic print of a smiling Mrs Vigil in her younger years. It was found on a desk at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 10
Name: Gregson's Photograph
Description: An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office, as if it was a treasured memory. An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office. The person on the left is Lord Klint van Zieks.
Evidence 11
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: Inspector Gregson's autopsy report, stating that death was instant, resulting from a bullet shot at close range. The autopsy report from the examination of Inspector Gregson's body. According to the coroner, Dr Gorey, an accurate estimation of the time of death is not possible.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Scene Floor Plan
Description: A plan of the small room in the building of flats on Fresno Street where the body of the victim, Inspector Gregson, was found.
Evidence 13
Name: Noticeboard
Description: A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper of the Bailey. A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper. There is a bloody handprint on the back side.
Evidence 14
Name: Venus Firecracker
Description: The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. What sort of bang could it make...? The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. It goes off like a gunshot.
Evidence 15
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim, Inspector Gregson. His body appears to be tightly curled up and there's a red hairpiece on his head.
Evidence 16
Name: Gregson's Pocket Watch
Description: Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. It's no longer ticking and the glass over the face is cracked. Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. Having wound it up, it's started ticking again.
Evidence 17
Name: Inspector's Identification
Description: The identification of a man claiming to be a detective inspector, confiscated by Mr de Rousseau and Mr de Rossi. Inspector Gregson's police identification. It's the official warrant card issued to him by Scotland Yard.
Evidence 18
Name: Commemorative Photograph
Description: A photograph taken in the foyer of the Great Waterloo Hotel on the morning of Professor Mikotoba and Judge Jigoku's arrival in London for the symposium.
Evidence 19
Name: The Asogi Papers
Description: The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. Apparently Mr Asogi described it as 'the only weapon I have left'. The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. It seems there was a third page to it.
Evidence 20
Name: Gregson's Trunk
Description: Inspector Gregson's metal travelling trunk that was removed from the scene, but subsequently recovered by Gina.
Evidence 21
Name: Passport
Description: A passport document that was in Inspector Gregson's possession. It was issued for travel to France the day before his body was discovered.
Evidence 22
Name: Klint's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the final victim of the infamous Professor. The report was authored by Dr John H. Wilson. The report from the autopsy of the Professor's final victim. It's signed by Dr John H. Wilson who carried out the procedure, though Professor Mikotoba actually penned the report.
Evidence 23
Name: Iris's Lucky Charm
Description: A little doll of Mr Sholmes in hare form. I've been told to tug its ears if I run out of options in the trial today...
Evidence 24
Name: Great Sword 'Karuma'
Description: The illustrious blade passed down through generations of the Asogi clan. The prized sword's tip has a small piece missing.
Evidence 25
Name: Evacuation Drill Itinerary
Description: A notice about a practice evacuation to be carried out by the crew of the SS Grouse the night before the ship arrived in Dover. It was found in Judge Jigoku's cabin.
Evidence 26

However, this method still occurs in Story Mode.)

Evidence 28
Name: Mr Asogi's Ring
Description: A ring belonging to Genshin Asogi found in Lord Klint van Zieks's stomach during the autopsy. The claws clasping the gem look sharp enough to cause a very nasty scratch.
Evidence 29
Name: Klint van Zieks's Will
Description: The last will and testament of Lord Klint van Zieks that has been hidden inside the great sword Karuma for years. A trump card left behind by Genshin Asogi.

cot:
Okay, let's see. I need to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let's start by going through the testimonies and evidences one by one.

Testimony 3 from Gossip says: "I ran into the room and there he woz. The Reaper, gun in hand, standin' over the dead body!" So Gossip claims that when he entered the room, he saw the Reaper (Barok van Zieks) holding the gun, standing over the victim.

Now, looking at the evidences. Evidence 7 is the Revolver, the murder weapon found at the scene. But if the Reaper was holding the gun, why was it left at the scene? Wait, maybe there's more. Let's check other evidences.

Evidence 16 is Gregson's Pocket Watch. The description says that after winding it, it started ticking again. But the watch was found cracked and stopped. If the watch stopped at the time of death, maybe the time of death can be determined. But the Autopsy Report (Evidence 11) states that the time of death couldn't be accurately estimated. Hmm, but how does that relate to the testimony?

Wait, Testimony 1 by Venus says they heard a big bang less than a minute after the Reaper went in. The Revolver is the gun used, but Evidence 14 is the Venus Firecracker, which goes off like a gunshot. Maybe the bang they heard was the firecracker, not the actual gunshot. So the testimony about hearing a bang might be contradicted by the firecracker evidence. But Testimony 1's person is Venus, who sells the firecrackers. Maybe she's lying or mistaken about the source of the bang.

Alternatively, Testimony 3 says the Reaper was holding the gun, but Evidence 17 is Inspector's Identification, which was confiscated by de Rousseau and de Rossi. Wait, that might not be directly related. Let me think again.

Looking at Testimony 3: Gossip claims he saw the Reaper with the gun. But the Revolver (Evidence 7) was found at the scene. If the Reaper was holding it, why leave it there? Unless he was framed. But maybe there's another angle. The testimony says he was holding the gun, but the actual murder weapon might have been a different one. Wait, no. The Revolver is stated as the murder weapon.

Wait, another angle: Testimony 4 by Gossip says he slipped and got blood on his hand, then wiped it on the floor. But Evidence 13 is the Noticeboard with a bloody handprint on the back. If Gossip wiped the blood on the floor, then the handprint on the noticeboard might be his. That could contradict his testimony about where he wiped the blood. But how does that relate to the evidence? If the handprint is on the noticeboard, but he said he wiped it on the floor, that's a contradiction. So Evidence 13 (Noticeboard with bloody handprint) contradicts Testimony 4 (wiped on floor). But I need to check if that's the case.

Wait, Testimony 4: "I slipped over and got blood on my hand, so I quickly wiped it off on the floor." If he wiped it on the floor, then the blood should be there. But Evidence 13's noticeboard has a bloody handprint on the back. So the handprint on the noticeboard would be from Gossip, which contradicts his testimony that he wiped it on the floor. Therefore, the evidence shows the handprint is on the noticeboard, but he claims to have wiped it on the floor. That's a contradiction. So Evidence 13 and Testimony 4 contradict each other. But is there another pair?

Alternatively, Testimony 3 (Gossip seeing Reaper with gun) and Evidence 17 (Inspector's Identification). Wait, Evidence 17 is Gregson's ID, which was confiscated by de Rousseau and de Rossi. If Gregson's ID was confiscated, how did he have it at the scene? Or maybe that's not relevant. Alternatively, maybe the confiscated ID is a fake, but that's not directly conflicting with Testimony 3.

Alternatively, Testimony 3 says Reaper was holding the gun, but Evidence 6 (Candelabrum) has a candle with the top blown off, which might suggest an explosion or another source of the bang. But the Revolver is the murder weapon. Hmm.

Wait, the key contradiction might be between Testimony 3 (Reaper holding gun) and the fact that the Revolver (Evidence 7) was found at the scene. If the Reaper had the gun, he would have taken it, but it was left there. But that's not necessarily a contradiction because maybe he dropped it. Alternatively, if the Revolver was found at the scene, then the Reaper might have been holding it, but that's not a contradiction. So maybe not.

Wait, another angle: Testimony 0 by Gossip says they saw everything from start to finish. But Testimony 2 by Sandwich says Gossip couldn't wait to go see what happened, implying that maybe Gossip wasn't there from the start. But that's between testimonies, not evidence and testimony.

Wait, what about the timing? Testimony 1 says the bang was less than a minute after Reaper went in. But the Autopsy Report (Evidence 11) says time of death can't be determined. If the testimony is about the timing, but the evidence can't confirm the time, that's not a direct contradiction.

Wait, going back to the handprint. If Gossip wiped the blood on the floor (Testimony 4), then the noticeboard's handprint (Evidence 13) must be from someone else. But if Gossip's handprint is on the noticeboard, then he's lying about where he wiped the blood. So Evidence 13 (bloody handprint on noticeboard) contradicts Testimony 4 (wiped on floor). That seems solid.

Alternatively, maybe the Revolver (Evidence 7) contradicts Testimony 3. If the Revolver was found at the scene, then the Reaper would have had to leave it there. But Testimony 3 says he was holding it. So if he left it, that's possible. So maybe no contradiction there.

Another possibility: Testimony 3 says the Reaper was holding the gun, but Evidence 14 (Venus Firecracker) makes a bang like a gunshot. So maybe the actual shot was from the firecracker, and the Revolver wasn't fired. But that's a stretch. If the Revolver is the murder weapon, then the firecracker's sound is a distraction. But how does that contradict testimony?

Alternatively, the passport (Evidence 21) shows Gregson was supposed to travel to France the next day. If he was planning to leave, maybe he had a motive, but not sure how that contradicts testimony.

Wait, the key contradiction is between Testimony 4 and Evidence 13. Gossip says he wiped blood on the floor, but the Noticeboard has a bloody handprint. Therefore, the evidence contradicts his testimony. So the answer should be evidence 13 and testimony 4.

First, I need to go through each testimony and see if any of the evidence entries can contradict them. Let's start by listing out the testimonies and see what each person is claiming.

Testimony 0 is from Gossip: "I don't know anythin' about that there noticeboard! I just wiped my hand on it, that's all." The noticeboard is Evidence 13, which mentions a bloody handprint on the back. Gossip claims he just wiped his hand, but the evidence has a bloody handprint. That could be a contradiction because if he only wiped his hand, maybe it's not blood. But I need to check if there's another evidence that directly contradicts this.

Testimony 1 is Venus saying she was doing business with some second years at the time. Not sure yet. Testimony 2 is Venus again admitting she peeked into the room. Maybe related to her alibi? Testimony 3 from Sandwich: "I, I don't know anything about anything. I'm j-just a bystander, me. J-Just a sign at the crossroads of life." Hmm. Is there evidence that shows Sandwich is involved? Looking at Evidence 15, which is a photograph of the victim, or maybe Evidence 9, the framed photograph of Mrs. Vigil found at the scene. Wait, maybe Sandwich is related to that?

Testimony 4: Gossip again blaming the Reaper. Not directly related to evidence. Testimony 5: Sandwich says the detective died when they heard the gunshot. But the Autopsy Report (Evidence 11) states that time of death couldn't be accurately determined. So if Sandwich claims the death happened exactly when the gunshot was heard, but the autopsy says the time isn't clear, that's a contradiction. However, the Revolver (Evidence 7) is the murder weapon, but maybe the Venus Firecracker (Evidence 14) which sounds like a gunshot. So if the gunshot they heard was actually the firecracker, then the actual time of death could be different. But how does that relate to the testimony?

Wait, Testimony 5 says "the detective still died when we heard the gunshot." If the murder was not by a gunshot but another method, or if the gunshot sound was a firecracker, then the time of death might not match. Let's check the Autopsy Report (Evidence 11): death was instant from a bullet at close range. So the cause of death is a gunshot. But the time of death couldn't be determined. So if the testimony claims the death was at the time of the gunshot, but the autopsy can't confirm the time, maybe that's not a direct contradiction. Hmm.
